text: BLUE REVISIONS
NOTEWORTHY
Written by
Johnny Fregosi
Based on a true story
johndanielfregosi@gmail.com
CAST LIST
Jay
Taylor
David
Drug Dealer
Cashier
Homeless Neighbor
Meeting Leader
Young Dude
Crackhead
LOCATION LIST
12 Step Meeting
• EXT. 12 Step Meeting
• Hallway/Stairs
• Main Room
DTLA Bodega
• EXT. DTLA Bodega
• Store
EXT. DTLA Filming Location
EXT. DTLA Sidewalk
EXT. DTLA Homeless Encampment
INT. Tent
INT. Jay’s Car
INT. Wasco State Prison
(MORE)
EXT. 12 STEP MEETING -- STREET -- DUSK
A used SYRINGE floats along a river of runoff along the curb
of a quiet Los Angeles street. The syringe hits several
items, damming up the running water, but always makes its way
through. Tilt up to reveal -
Warm light radiates from a 12-step meeting hall. The roar of
CLAPPING from inside prompts a few highly-caffeinated meeting
STRAGGLERS to make their way inside.
INT. 12 STEP MEETING -- HALLWAY
At the top of a stairway, a DOORWAY is illuminated from the
opposite side where a meeting goer finishes a reading -
MEETING LEADER (O.S.)
...Our primary purpose is to stay
sober and help other alcoholics to
achieve sobriety. Please silence
your cellphones and take all
conversations outside.
We follow the STRAGGLERS up the stairs as they break frame
and enter the meeting space through the door -
INT. 12 STEP MEETING -- MAIN ROOM -- CONTINUOUS
A dimly-lit room, packed with people of all ages and
backgrounds. The MEETING LEADER still reading from a prompt -
MEETING LEADER

children.text: Now, please help me give a warm
welcome to tonight's speaker - Jay!

text: Now, please help me give a warm
welcome to tonight's speaker - Jay!
The ritualistic clapping erupts as a clean-cut man rises from
the front row and takes the Meeting Leader's spot at the
podium. This man is JAY (30).
JAY

children.text: Hey, my name is Jay, I'm an
alcoholic.

text: Hey, my name is Jay, I'm an
alcoholic.
ENTIRE ROOM

children.text: Hey Jay.

text: Hey Jay.
JAY

children.text: I also used drugs, lots of 'em. Whether
that's your story or not, I'm happy
you're here. I hate public speaking,
but here goes nothing. My sobriety date
is June 2nd, 2018.

text: I also used drugs, lots of 'em. Whether
that's your story or not, I'm happy
you're here. I hate public speaking,
but here goes nothing. My sobriety date
is June 2nd, 2018.
(MORE)
JAY (CONT'D)

children.text: This isn't my first time getting sober,
but I pray it's my last.

text: This isn't my first time getting sober,
but I pray it's my last.
(beat)

children.text: I'll save you the childhood trauma
shit, because everyone has that.
None of that made me an alcoholic.
The first time I drank, I was 12.
Gin, vodka, whatever I could
Gin, vodka, whatever I could
find... got alcohol poisoning,
cheated on my girlfriend, got
caught by my parents. When I woke
up two days later, the first thing
I thought was "that was great, when
can I do that again?"

text: I'll save you the childhood trauma
shit, because everyone has that.
None of that made me an alcoholic.
The first time I drank, I was 12.
Gin, vodka, whatever I could
find... got alcohol poisoning,
cheated on my girlfriend, got
caught by my parents. When I woke
up two days later, the first thing
I thought was "that was great, when
can I do that again?"
An identifying giggle ripples through the meeting.
JAY

children.text: I'd found the solution to problems
I never knew I had, and once I
started, I could not stop. Alcohol,
Xanax, painkillers, and then it was
ultimately anything I could
dissolve in water and slam into
whatever vein was left. I wake up
every day grateful I'm not living
that way anymore, because the fun
stopped a LONG time ago. Getting
here and staying here wasn't
easy...

text: (CONT'D)
I'd found the solution to problems
I never knew I had, and once I
started, I could not stop. Alcohol,
Xanax, painkillers, and then it was
ultimately anything I could
dissolve in water and slam into
whatever vein was left. I wake up
every day grateful I'm not living
that way anymore, because the fun
stopped a LONG time ago. Getting
here and staying here wasn't
easy...
INTERCUT
INT. JAY'S CAR -- FLASHBACK -- DAWN
Jay's hands tremble as he white-knuckles the steering wheel on
his way to work. The world passes by the windows in a BLUR.
JAY (V.O.)

children.text: At a year sober, my life on the
outside looked amazing. Mom and Dad
were proud, but I was dying inside.
I didn’t get sober to feel like
I didn't get sober to feel like
fucking shit, ya know? Something
was definitely missing, but I told
myself I was too busy to figure it
out. One morning I was late as fuck
to work, and on my drive there, it
was either get high or off myself.
Maybe something quick and painless,
Maybe something quick and painless,
like driving my car off a bridge or
something.

text: At a year sober, my life on the
outside looked amazing. Mom and Dad
were proud, but I was dying inside.
I didn't get sober to feel like
fucking shit, ya know? Something
was definitely missing, but I told
myself I was too busy to figure it
out. One morning I was late as fuck
to work, and on my drive there, it
was either get high or off myself.
Maybe something quick and painless,
like driving my car off a bridge or
something.
JAY (CONT'D)
Jay has a BREAKDOWN while driving. It boils over with
FRUSTRATION and ANGER as he PUNCHES the steering wheel.
JAY

children.text: FUCK!!!

text: (in car)
FUCK!!!
INT. JAY'S CAR -- FLASHBACK -- MOMENTS LATER
Jay parks his car at work, catching a glimpse of himself in
the rearview. He bangs his head against the headrest -
JAY (V.O.)

children.text: I made it to work, but I was ready
to throw it all away and call my
guy.

text: I made it to work, but I was ready
to throw it all away and call my
guy.
He digs out his phone and scrolls through to an old drug-
dealer's contact card. At some point, Jay explicitly labeled
this person as "DEATH".
His finger hovers over the call icon.
Then - the phone RINGS. It reads: "Boss Lady". He realizes
the TIME, answers -
JAY

children.text: Yeah I'm parking. Sorry. Yeah, be
there soon. Copy. Yup, bye.

text: Yeah I'm parking. Sorry. Yeah, be
there soon. Copy. Yup, bye.
JAY (V.O.)

children.text: Luckily, I was working 80 hour
weeks.

text: Luckily, I was working 80 hour
weeks.
INT. 12 STEP MEETING -- MAIN ROOM -- RESUME
Jay takes a sip of water at the podium. People are nodding
their heads, relating.
JAY

children.text: Being that busy was a great way to
distract myself from those early-
recovery cravings. And my
recovery cravings. And my
relentless desire to fuck anything
that walked... I know, there's
other programs for that.
The crowd laughs, identifying.

text: Being that busy was a great way to
distract myself from those early-
recovery cravings. And my
relentless desire to fuck anything
that walked... I know, there's
other programs for that.
The crowd laughs, identifying.
JAY

children.text: But by using work as a distraction,
I convinced myself I was doing
enough to stay sober. Everyone I
knew thought I had it all figured
out, but I was falling apart. We
get sober to have a better, more
meaningful life. I was sober, but I
was fucking miserable and nobody
knew it. So, I went into work and
threw on a smile. We are all so
fucking good at faking it.

text: (CONT'D)
But by using work as a distraction,
I convinced myself I was doing
enough to stay sober. Everyone I
knew thought I had it all figured
out, but I was falling apart. We
get sober to have a better, more
meaningful life. I was sober, but I
was fucking miserable and nobody
knew it. So, I went into work and
threw on a smile. We are all so
fucking good at faking it.
(beat)

children.text: But right before lunch that day,
I'd made up my mind.

text: But right before lunch that day,
I'd made up my mind.
INTERCUT
EXT. DTLA FILMING LOCATION -- FLASHBACK
A FILM CREW litters the sidewalk outside a dwelling. Jay is a
production assistant in need of a nap. He locks up the
entrance to a building, stirring on this decision. On auto-
pilot, his hand retrieves his phone from his pocket. We hear
the sound of clicking letters as the words appear on the
screen -
CHYRON: JAY - Yo, what's good? I'm coming through. Cool?
Jay sends the text and stuffs his phone back into his pocket.
Just then, noise from his earpiece prompts him -
JAY

children.text: WE CUT! That's lunch, 1 hour!

text: WE CUT! That's lunch, 1 hour!
The crew is relieved. Jay props open the doors to the set,
crew flows out. Jay "spins the channels" on his walkie
talkie.
JAY

children.text: That's lunch, assholes. Back in at 4.

text: (CONT'D)
(into walkie)
That's lunch, assholes. Back in at 4.
(beat)

children.text: Hey camera pricks, back in at 4.

text: Hey camera pricks, back in at 4.
An incoherent COMEDIC YELLING comes from the walkie, Jay
laughs, but the joy is short-lived. His smile quickly falls,
revealing this lighthearted moment to be a daily facade. His
phone buzzes -
CHYRON: DEATH - Look who the fuck it is. Hit me up when
you're here.
Jay takes a deep breath, looks around. Fuck it. As he leaves
his post, going a DIFFERENT direction than the breaking crew,
Jay crashes into A MAN. After the collision, seen only for a
SPLIT SECOND: This MAN is a disheveled, sunken-in version of
HIMSELF. In a BLINK, this version of Jay disappears, and an
equally disheveled young MAN takes his place. This Man is
TAYLOR (30s), and he instinctively gets defensive.
TAYLOR

children.text: Yo, watch where the fu-

text: Yo, watch where the fu-
When Taylor realizes WHO he has almost run into, his voice
falls silent and the AUDIO around them cuts out completely. No
city noises, no footsteps, no talking. Just Jay and Taylor.
The SHOCK on Jay's face paints a picture...these men know each
other.
JAY

children.text: Taylor? Holy SHIT man.

text: Taylor? Holy SHIT man.
INT. 12 STEP MEETING -- MAIN ROOM -- RESUME
Jay takes a sip of water and continues his story.
JAY

children.text: Some of you know Taylor A. If you
don't, I wish you did. The dude's
fucking talented -

text: Some of you know Taylor A. If you
don't, I wish you did. The dude's
fucking talented -
INTERCUT
EXT. 12 STEP MEETING -- DUSK -- FLASHBACK
CHYRON: 3 years earlier.
After a meeting, a small group of meeting-goers, including
Jay, circle around Taylor as he sings the vocals to his own
song.
JAY (V.O.)

children.text: 3 years prior, we were just getting
sober. I felt like I had no
passions or purpose in my life. But
Taylor... he had the gift of music.
Watching him share that passion
Watching him share that passion
inspired me to look for mine. I
ended up in film because of him.
Taylor really fucking moved me.

text: 3 years prior, we were just getting
sober. I felt like I had no
passions or purpose in my life. But
Taylor... he had the gift of music.
Watching him share that passion
inspired me to look for mine. I
ended up in film because of him.
Taylor really fucking moved me.
Jay hypes Taylor up, tears welling. He sings along, a big fan
of Taylor's music. The other sober friends loosen up and jam
with Jay and Taylor.
INT. 12 STEP MEETING -- MAIN ROOM -- RESUME
The meeting is invested in the story Jay is telling.
JAY

children.text: I couldn't believe my eyes. It had
been a long time since I'd seen
him. He looked like dog shit, if
I'm being honest. But I missed the
fuck outta him.

text: I couldn't believe my eyes. It had
been a long time since I'd seen
him. He looked like dog shit, if
I'm being honest. But I missed the
fuck outta him.
INTERCUT
EXT. DTLA FILMING LOCATION -- FLASHBACK
Taylor analyzes Jay, his situation.
TAYLOR

children.text: Jay... What are you doing down
here?
Jay points to the set.

text: Jay... What are you doing down
here?
Jay points to the set.
JAY

children.text: Dude.. it.. I work here.

text: Dude.. it.. I work here.
(beat)

children.text: Been on set for like a year.

text: Been on set for like a year.
Taylor cracks a short-lived genuine smile.
TAYLOR

children.text: Y'all making movies or some shit?
That’s hella cool dude. I knew
That's hella cool dude. I knew
you'd do big things.

text: Y'all making movies or some shit?
That's hella cool dude. I knew
you'd do big things.
Jay smiles back. A different smile than the fake one we saw
just moments ago. A long beat.
JAY

children.text: You good...
Taylor's eyes fall to his feet.

text: You good...
Taylor's eyes fall to his feet.
TAYLOR

children.text: Me? I am fucking great man...

text: Me? I am fucking great man...
JAY

children.text: There is always a seat for you on
Saturday.

text: There is always a seat for you on
Saturday.
Taylor tries to mouth a response, but is overwhelmed, itches
his nose. Jay doesn't need a response. He's been there
before.
JAY

children.text: I never thought I'd see you again.

text: (CONT'D)
I never thought I'd see you again.
TAYLOR

children.text: Sorry I just dipped.

text: Sorry I just dipped.
JAY

children.text: Sorry?! Nah. Just glad you're still
kicking.

text: Sorry?! Nah. Just glad you're still
kicking.
(beat)

children.text: I tried to hit you up.

text: I tried to hit you up.
TAYLOR

children.text: Yeah... been using public phones
for a while, ya know?
Jay gets it.

text: Yeah... been using public phones
for a while, ya know?
Jay gets it.
JAY

children.text: Well, let me give you my number?

text: Well, let me give you my number?
Taylor nods. Jay pulls out a pen and tears off a piece of
paper from something production related. Taylor's discomfort
on full display while Jay writes. Jay folds the note and
hands it to Taylor.
JAY

children.text: Really fucking good to see you,
man.

text: (CONT'D)
Really fucking good to see you,
man.
(beat, re: note)

children.text: Don't lose that.

text: Don't lose that.
A dogtown-type grip, DAVID (50s) passes by with a plate of
food. Jay watches Taylor's eye track the food -
JAY

children.text: Dude...you look like shit. Please
let me get you some food, wait
right here. I'll be right
back...don't fucking go anywhere.

text: (CONT'D)
Dude...you look like shit. Please
let me get you some food, wait
right here. I'll be right
back...don't fucking go anywhere.
TAYLOR

children.text: Aight.

text: Aight.
EXT. DTLA SIDEWALK -- CONTINUOUS
We follow Jay down the sidewalk, he gets stopped by a CREW
MEMBER. The SILENCE continues as Jay talks to this person. We
can SEE Taylor in the background. Behind the cover of passing
Crew Members, Taylor DISAPPEARS.
EXT. DTLA FILMING LOCATION -- MOMENTS LATER
Jay returns to the filming location with two to-go
containers, but realizes that Taylor is GONE. The chaotic
AUDIO of downtown LA has resumed.
Jay runs down the sidewalk in one direction, then the other,
Taylor nowhere to be found. The grip, David, steps off the
tailgate of his truck.
JAY

children.text: Yo, did you see where that guy
went?

text: Yo, did you see where that guy
went?
DAVID

children.text: The homeless dude?

text: The homeless dude?
JAY

children.text: Yeah, the homeless dude.

text: Yeah, the homeless dude.
DAVID

children.text: I missed it, kid. He kinda just
disappeared.

text: I missed it, kid. He kinda just
disappeared.
JAY

children.text: He does that.

text: He does that.
DAVID

children.text: Who was he?

text: Who was he?
JAY

children.text: He's an old friend. We got sober
together. A talented artist.
David is skeptical.

text: He's an old friend. We got sober
together. A talented artist.
David is skeptical.
DAVID

children.text: That zombie is a talented artist?
Jay nods.

text: That zombie is a talented artist?
Jay nods.
JAY

children.text: He was just gone one day, always
wondered where he went. Guess now I
know.

text: He was just gone one day, always
wondered where he went. Guess now I
know.
DAVID

children.text: This city swallows 'em up.
Jay kicks at the sidewalk.

text: This city swallows 'em up.
Jay kicks at the sidewalk.
JAY

children.text: I always wanted that.

text: I always wanted that.
DAVID

children.text: To burn your life to the ground?

text: To burn your life to the ground?
Jay takes a beat to soak that in. Ironic.
JAY

children.text: No, dickhead. How to use my voice,
express myself.

text: No, dickhead. How to use my voice,
express myself.
DAVID

children.text: You're on the right path, I
promise.

text: (softens)
You're on the right path, I
promise.
JAY

children.text: If I am, it's thanks to him.

text: If I am, it's thanks to him.
(beat)

children.text: I gotta find him.

text: I gotta find him.
Jay breaks away to approach two HOMELESS PEOPLE (20s) posted
up nearby. David watches from afar, empathizing.  Jay moves
into the Homeless Encampment, out of David's view.
EXT. DTLA HOMELESS ENCAMPMENT -- CONTINUOUS
Jay shows two Homeless People something on his phone, points
to where he and Taylor collided. They shake their heads.
INT. 12 STEP MEETING -- MAIN ROOM -- RESUME
Jay's eyes look toward the ceiling as he recalls the story,
then back to the audience as he continues -
JAY

children.text: Running into him that day saved my
life. I forgot about getting high,
and all I worried about was finding
Taylor. Like it was instinctive.
Seeing him like that made me
Seeing him like that made me
realize what a relapse would look
like. None of it looked good. The
amount of people that helped me get
onto that film set? Fuck. How
selfish that would have been to
throw away.

text: Running into him that day saved my
life. I forgot about getting high,
and all I worried about was finding
Taylor. Like it was instinctive.
Seeing him like that made me
realize what a relapse would look
like. None of it looked good. The
amount of people that helped me get
onto that film set? Fuck. How
selfish that would have been to
throw away.
INTERCUT
EXT. DTLA HOMELESS ENCAMPMENT -- MONTAGE
MONTAGE: Over the course of two years, Jay walks up to the
two HOMELESS PEOPLE several times, checking if they've seen
Taylor. It never looks as though they have.
JAY (V.O.)

children.text: Unfortunately, I haven't heard from
him, but I looked for him all the
time. I pray for him everyday.

text: Unfortunately, I haven't heard from
him, but I looked for him all the
time. I pray for him everyday.
During one of the visits, a DRUG DEALER gets agitated with
Jay's presence.
DRUG DEALER

children.text: Motherfucker, he ain't coming back.
He’s gone. Give it up and stay the
He's gone. Give it up and stay the
fuck outta here unless you're here
to buy.

text: Motherfucker, he ain't coming back.
He's gone. Give it up and stay the
fuck outta here unless you're here
to buy.
INT. 12 STEP MEETING -- MAIN ROOM -- RESUME
Jay stands at the podium.
JAY

children.text: I was going to meetings when I
could, being a decent dude, working
my ass off. But I wasn't giving
away what was given to me here in
these rooms. I just wasn't. Seeing
Taylor on that day was more than a
coincidence, and I tried my best to
help him. That's what recovery is
all about, and use me as an
example... skimping on being of
service will get you high. If I can
leave you with one thing, it's
this: there is someone who needs
what you have to offer. Offer it,
even when you don't believe you
have anything to offer. Even when
they can't accept it. Especially
then. I'm Jay, I'm grateful to be
sober today. Thanks for letting me
share.

text: I was going to meetings when I
could, being a decent dude, working
my ass off. But I wasn't giving
away what was given to me here in
these rooms. I just wasn't. Seeing
Taylor on that day was more than a
coincidence, and I tried my best to
help him. That's what recovery is
all about, and use me as an
example... skimping on being of
service will get you high. If I can
leave you with one thing, it's
this: there is someone who needs
what you have to offer. Offer it,
even when you don't believe you
have anything to offer. Even when
they can't accept it. Especially
then. I'm Jay, I'm grateful to be
sober today. Thanks for letting me
share.
The uniform applause fills the room. He takes a seat nearby
as the applause fades out.
The Meeting Leader takes the podium, she reads from a prompt -
MEETING LEADER

children.text: Madison, alcoholic.

text: Madison, alcoholic.
EVERYONE

children.text: Hi Madison.

text: Hi Madison.
MEETING LEADER

children.text: Thank you, Jay. It's now time for
birthdays. Birthdays are defined as
365 days of continuous sobriety.
Today, we have one birthday...
She flips a page to a handwritten name.

text: Thank you, Jay. It's now time for
birthdays. Birthdays are defined as
365 days of continuous sobriety.
Today, we have one birthday...
She flips a page to a handwritten name.
MEETING LEADER

children.text: ...for Taylor with 2 years.

text: (CONT'D)
...for Taylor with 2 years.
The buzz in the room falls into silence.
MEETING LEADER

children.text: Cake given to him by...Jay.

text: (CONT'D)
Cake given to him by...Jay.
From shadows in the back of the room, TAYLOR stands. He looks
like a different person. And has about TWICE the amount of
tattoos. He looks HEALTHY and is visibly moved by Jay's
share. People in the crowd murmur, disbelieving.
Jay waits a few moments... Did he faint? What's happening? He
turns back and sees TAYLOR approaching the podium. They share
a powerful moment as Jay stands to greet him.
An OLD-TIMER lights 2 candles on a fake cake and hands it to
Jay. A few other meeting goers pop up to join in a close
huddle as the room sings -
ENTIRE ROOM

children.text: "Happy birthday to you. Happy
birthday to you! Happy birthday
dear Taylor. Happy birthday to you.
Keep coming back! Sober!"

text: "Happy birthday to you. Happy
birthday to you! Happy birthday
dear Taylor. Happy birthday to you.
Keep coming back! Sober!"
Taylor blows the candles out, gives hugs to mutual friends of
he and Jay's... then he and Jay embrace. A powerful wave of
energy flows through the room, as the applause continues for
what feels an eternity. As the clapping simmers down, Jay and
Taylor release and Taylor commands the room from the podium.
Jay takes his seat.
TAYLOR

children.text: Wassup, I'm Taylor, alcoholic.

text: Wassup, I'm Taylor, alcoholic.
ENTIRE ROOM

children.text: Hi, Taylor.

text: Hi, Taylor.
Taylor laughs. Not a "that's funny" laugh. It's more a holy
shit type of laugh. He looks around the room, he's a little
crowd-shy, but powers through.
TAYLOR

children.text: Holy fuck.

text: Holy fuck.
(beat)

children.text: If you're questioning whether or
not this was set up... honestly
kinda. I heard my homie Jay was
speaking. I didn't know he'd be
telling our whole fucking story.

text: If you're questioning whether or
not this was set up... honestly
kinda. I heard my homie Jay was
speaking. I didn't know he'd be
telling our whole fucking story.
An ELDERLY WOMAN hands Jay a tissue, he mouths "thanks".
TAYLOR

children.text: It was just another Friday for me -

text: (CONT'D)
It was just another Friday for me -
INTERCUT
EXT. DTLA HOMELESS ENCAMPMENT -- FLASHBACK
It's the morning of Jay and Taylor's run-in. Taylor is the
customer of a sidewalk drug deal. Taylor unzips a greasy
duffel bag at the feet of the sleazy Drug Dealer. He presents
two pairs of freshly shoplifted jeans.
TAYLOR

children.text: Tags still on 'em. They run 300 a
pop, retail.

text: Tags still on 'em. They run 300 a
pop, retail.
DRUG DEALER

children.text: What the fuck I been telling you,
Tay? Do I look like a thrift shop
to you?

text: What the fuck I been telling you,
Tay? Do I look like a thrift shop
to you?
Taylor glances around at his hell-scape of a "neighborhood".
TAYLOR

children.text: C'mon, nobody I run with has the
money to spend on these. Offerin'
them to you dirt cheap, man.

text: C'mon, nobody I run with has the
money to spend on these. Offerin'
them to you dirt cheap, man.
DRUG DEALER

children.text: Nah, you trading these to me for
dope because you're a 'lil fiend.

text: (aggressively)
Nah, you trading these to me for
dope because you're a 'lil fiend.
TAYLOR

children.text: One gram? I'll bring you bread from
now on, swear.

text: One gram? I'll bring you bread from
now on, swear.
The Drug Dealer snatches the jeans from Taylor.
DRUG DEALER

children.text: Half gram.

text: Half gram.
The Dealer slams a HALF GRAM OF TAR HEROIN packaged in a
small red balloon into Taylor's palm. Taylor is defeated.
DRUG DEALER

children.text: I told you this shit already. Don't
come around if you ain't got dough.
Don't care if you fiending later.
Cash only.

text: (CONT'D)
I told you this shit already. Don't
come around if you ain't got dough.
Don't care if you fiending later.
Cash only.
TAYLOR

children.text: Aight man, I hear you.

text: Aight man, I hear you.
Taylor goes in for a fist bump, but a MANIC CRACKHEAD gets
the attention of the Drug Dealer first.
CRACKHEAD

children.text: Ayo wassup muh-fucka, you got some
rock? I got this bike, fresh off
the lot.

text: Ayo wassup muh-fucka, you got some
rock? I got this bike, fresh off
the lot.
The Crackhead yanks a tarp off a 10 speed bicycle, smiles
proudly. Taylor heads for his tent as -
DRUG DEALER

children.text: Y'all killin' me down here, man.

text: (shaking head)
Y'all killin' me down here, man.
INT. TENT -- MOMENTS LATER
Sunshine infiltrates the dingy interior of a tent through
several tears in it's walls.
Taylor's shaky hands dig through a shoebox for something - he
retrieves a SYRINGE to see that the needle is BENT.
He attempts to straighten it, but it BREAKS off the syringe.
Taylor SMACKS the wall of the tent.
TAYLOR

children.text: GOD DAMNIT!
You good in there, T?

text: GOD DAMNIT!
Taylor desperately tries to re-attach the needle, to no
avail.
HOMELESS NEIGHBOR (O.S.)
You good in there, T?
A tear wells. Taylor is FRUSTRATED, sick.
TAYLOR

children.text: Yeah, bro. I'm good. I need a rig,
you got one?

text: Yeah, bro. I'm good. I need a rig,
you got one?
The Homeless Neighbor (one of the same HOMELESS PEOPLE from
earlier) pokes her head into the tent.
HOMELESS NEIGHBOR

children.text: I got a used one.

text: I got a used one.
Taylor's forehead falls against his tucked knees. A decision
to be made. One no human being desires to make. The reality:
he has no choice.
TAYLOR

children.text: Aight, yeah sure.

text: Aight, yeah sure.
The Homeless Neighbor wields a USED SYRINGE, the interior
caked with dried blood. Taylor takes it from her.
TAYLOR

children.text: Thanks, I'll get you back.

text: (CONT'D)
Thanks, I'll get you back.
The Homeless Neighbor nods before leaving.
INT. TENT -- VARIOUS
QUICK CUTS of the RITUAL of heroin use in Taylor's tent.
EXT. DTLA STREET -- LATER THAT DAY
Taylor leans against a graffiti-ridden wall, smokes a hand-
rolled cigarette. He turns the HEROIN BALLOON inside-out.
Scrapes at the remnants with his dirty fingernail.
TAYLOR (V.O.)

children.text: That needle may look small, but I
fit my whole life into that shit.
My family, my love for music, my
My family, my love for music, my
fucking dignity. All gone, just
like that. I got high that morning,
but by 4pm I was sick and broke
again. So, I was gonna do what I
needed to do.

text: That needle may look small, but I
fit my whole life into that shit.
My family, my love for music, my
fucking dignity. All gone, just
like that. I got high that morning,
but by 4pm I was sick and broke
again. So, I was gonna do what I
needed to do.
From his pocket, Taylor slides out a weathered PISTOL. His
hands are already clammy, shaky. He's WITHDRAWING,
contemplating. He goes -
TAYLOR (V.O.)

children.text: That's when it happened.

text: That's when it happened.
EXT. DTLA FILMING LOCATION -- FLASHBACK
CLOSE ON: Jay's NOTE in Taylor's hand. Pull back to reveal -
we are outside the Filming Location where Jay and Taylor
collided. Jay walks away to get them lunch -
TAYLOR (V.O.)

children.text: Whatever he was going through that
day, he hid it well. And he offered
to help anyway... because fuck, I
really needed it. But as soon as I
could, I ran. I always run.

text: Whatever he was going through that
day, he hid it well. And he offered
to help anyway... because fuck, I
really needed it. But as soon as I
could, I ran. I always run.
Taylor waits for Jay to return, the world still SILENT. He
looks around at the healthy film crew swarming the sidewalk,
chews a fingernail. He fights with something. He's out of
place, naked, ashamed. He looks at Jay's note, then RUNS.
EXT. DTLA BODEGA -- FLASHBACK -- MOMENTS LATER
Taylor RUNS from around a corner, stops. Checks his POCKET
again. Shakes his head, looks around the corner toward the
FILM SET. Leaves again, comes back. Indecisive. Then - he
enters the store.
INT. DTLA BODEGA -- FLASHBACK
A typical Los Angeles bodega. Taylor nervously scans the BEER
fridge. The CASHIER eyes him suspiciously from across the
store. Taylor chooses his poison, a 40oz OLDE ENGLISH.
Taylor approaches the counter. The CASHIER looks concerned.
CASHIER

children.text: That all today?

text: That all today?
A YOUNG DUDE enters the front door, the bell DINGING. Taylor
eyes them, then back to Cashier.
TAYLOR

children.text: Yeah, that's it.

text: Yeah, that's it.
He slides the 40oz across the counter, Cashier rings it up.
CASHIER

children.text: Two ninety-eight.

text: Two ninety-eight.
The cashier tenses up while Taylor digs in his pocket. After
some time, Taylor pulls out a handful of change. Thumbs it
around in his palm. The Cashier looks relieved. JUST THEN -
Taylor pulls the PISTOL out of the other pocket, points it at
the Cashier!
TAYLOR

children.text: Empty the fuckin' register!

text: Empty the fuckin' register!
He throws his backpack on the counter. The Cashier reaches
for something, maybe a phone or an emergency-button? Taylor
plays with the trigger, shaking the gun inches from the
Cashier's face. Tears well on Taylor, he's desperate.
TAYLOR

children.text: Just do it man, please!

text: (CONT'D)
Just do it man, please!
(beat, impatient)

children.text: MONEY IN THE BAG!

text: MONEY IN THE BAG!
Taylor becomes frantic. Looks back to the Young Dude, who is
like a deer in headlights.
TAYLOR

children.text: Get the fuck outta here man, just
go! Go!

text: (CONT'D)
Get the fuck outta here man, just
go! Go!
YOUNG DUDE

children.text: I didn't see anything man!

text: I didn't see anything man!
The Young Dude takes the opportunity and JETS for the door
with a case of Bud Light. Taylor turns back -
TAYLOR

children.text: Hurry the fuck up!

text: Hurry the fuck up!
CASHIER

children.text: Alright!

text: Alright!
(under breath)

children.text: Goddamn junkie.

text: Goddamn junkie.
He stuffs what appears to be a few hundred dollars into the
bag while Taylor scans the premises and bolts out the door -
EXT. DTLA BODEGA -- CONTINUOUS
Taylor flees the scene of the robbery, the SOUND of POLICE
SIRENS echo from afar.
EXT. DTLA FILMING LOCATION -- THAT MOMENT -- FLASHBACK
Jay hangs his feet off the tailgate of the Grip truck. He is
eating lunch, and next to him is an untouched to-go box
marked with sharpie: TAYLOR. His phone buzzes, he checks it -
CHYRON: DEATH - WHERE YOU AT BRUH?
A BARRAGE of SIRENS (headed for Taylor at the Bodega) echo
through the city block, catching Jay's attention, but only
for a brief moment. Jay locks his phone, lays it face down.
INT. WASCO STATE PRISON -- PHONES -- FLASHBACK
Taylor, in correctional garb, sits by a PRISON PHONE. He is
BADLY bruised, sunken in. He looks worse than he did earlier.
TAYLOR (V.O.)

children.text: I got popped and spent two years in
prison. I kept getting loaded
inside, even after all that shit.
Same problems, different
Same problems, different
environment. No money, getting my
ass beat. I was so fucking wrecked
and I thought of Jay a lot. Wished
I had the courage to stay that day.

text: I got popped and spent two years in
prison. I kept getting loaded
inside, even after all that shit.
Same problems, different
environment. No money, getting my
ass beat. I was so fucking wrecked
and I thought of Jay a lot. Wished
I had the courage to stay that day.
Taylor flips open a BOOK, and hidden within the pages is THE
NOTE that Jay gave him on that Friday.
TAYLOR (V.O.)

children.text: I thought that I'd probably die on
the streets or in prison, but I
held onto Jay's note like my life
depended on it.

text: I thought that I'd probably die on
the streets or in prison, but I
held onto Jay's note like my life
depended on it.
Taylor picks up the phone and begins dialing a phone number,
but slams the receiver. His head in his hands.
TAYLOR (V.O.)

children.text: I remember hearing in meetings that
the phone can weigh a thousand
pounds. But on that note, below his
phone number, was something that
kept me going.

text: I remember hearing in meetings that
the phone can weigh a thousand
pounds. But on that note, below his
phone number, was something that
kept me going.
Over Taylor's shoulder, we SEE the words on Jay's note. Below
his phone number, it reads -
TAYLOR (V.O.)

children.text: You don't have to keep living like
this. You are worth more, and I
love you.

text: You don't have to keep living like
this. You are worth more, and I
love you.
Next to the phones is a PRISON SCHEDULE. Taylor slides a
finger through the words and lands on something: "12 STEP
MEETING - LIBRARY 7AM"
INT. 12 STEP MEETING -- MAIN ROOM -- RESUME
The silence in the room is so powerful, the static from the
microphone seems as loud as a jetliner.
TAYLOR

children.text: I wasn't ready to call him, I
didn't want to disappoint him.
Maybe I wasn't sure I'd get sober.
But reading that note eventually
But reading that note eventually
got me to a meeting. I've been
sober since.

text: I wasn't ready to call him, I
didn't want to disappoint him.
Maybe I wasn't sure I'd get sober.
But reading that note eventually
got me to a meeting. I've been
sober since.
(beat)

children.text: Sounds like running into each other
saved us both, brother.
Taylor looks to Jay, continues -

text: Sounds like running into each other
saved us both, brother.
Taylor looks to Jay, continues -
TAYLOR

children.text: It's crazy. You really never know
whose life you can change by
offering a helping hand. I thank my
higher power, these rooms, and Jay
for saving mine.

text: (CONT'D)
It's crazy. You really never know
whose life you can change by
offering a helping hand. I thank my
higher power, these rooms, and Jay
for saving mine.
Taylor pulls Jay's weathered NOTE out from his pocket, waves
it in the air next to him, looks at Jay -
TAYLOR

children.text: Same number?

text: (CONT'D)
Same number?
JAY

children.text: Same number fucker.

text: (from audience)
Same number fucker.
Taylor steps down from the podium, he and Jay embrace once
again. The applause ERUPTS in the room. Over this -
JAY

children.text: You been hiding in the back or
something, you little fuckin' weirdo?
Jay shoves him jokingly.

text: (CONT'D)
You been hiding in the back or
something, you little fuckin' weirdo?
Jay shoves him jokingly.
TAYLOR

children.text: Didn't wanna make you nervous
bitch. You're welcome.
My name is Madison, I'm still an
alcoholic.

text: Didn't wanna make you nervous
bitch. You're welcome.
Taylor and Jay take a seat next to each other now. The
Meeting Leader makes her way back to the podium.
Jay's phone BUZZES in his pocket. He slides it out and
unlocks it, Taylor not paying attention.
CHYRON: DEATH - You still coming through tonight?
PUSH IN ON: Jay's VACANT glare.
MEETING LEADER (O.S.)
My name is Madison, I'm still an
alcoholic.
Jay mouths "Hi Madison" along with the rest of the room -
EVERYONE

children.text: Hi Madison.

text: Hi Madison.
FADE TO BLACK.
